Package com.taco.tacository.util.tools.list_tools

Class OperationHandler<E>

java.lang.Object
com.taco.tacository.util.tools.list_tools.OperationHandler<E>
Type Parameters:
E - The type of element contained within the list that has been assigned to this OperationHandler.
All Implemented Interfaces:
Lockable, OperationListener<E>, UID, UIDProcessable, com.taco.tacository._to_sort.obj_traits.common.Nameable, Lock, javafx.collections.ListChangeListener<E>
public abstract class OperationHandler<E> extends Object implements OperationListener<E>, javafx.collections.ListChangeListener<E>, Lockable, com.taco.tacository._to_sort.obj_traits.common.Nameable, UIDProcessable

An abstract implementation of both ListChangeListener and OperationListener.

Details

  1. OperationHandler objects are constructed by ListTools.wrap(...) and other factory methods in the ListTools utility class.
    • Most factory methods return a OperationHandler that was constructed using ListTools.wrap(...).
  2. The primary function of OperationHandler is to streamline the event data provided by ListChangeListener#onChanged(Change).
  3. OperationHandler uses Operation records to communicate a Change Event.

Auto Conversion

By default, an OperationHandler will attempt to detect ObservableList add and remove operations that are functionally permutations â€” e.g. Collections.shuffle(List).

  1. If such an Operation exists, the add and remove operations that comprise the inferred permutation are no longer triggered as add or remove events, but rather converted and submitted as a single permutation event.
  2. To disable automatic permutation conversions, set Smart Convert to false.

Known Functions Behavior

Below outline List manipulation functions and thir permutation behavior.

With Smart Convert Permutation Event Support

  1. FXCollections.shuffle(ObservableList)

Without Smart Convert Permutation Event Support

  1. Collections.shuffle(List)

With Native Permutation Event Support

  1. ArrayTools.sort(List)

Example Output

Refer to ListToolsDemo.

    • onUpdate

      public void onUpdate​(int from, int to)
      Description copied from interface: OperationListener

      Executed once in response to a updation operation that occurred in a single Change Event step.

      Details

      • List operations that utilize this event type are rare, and therefore this method typically be ignored in favor of permutate, add, and remove event responses.
      Specified by:
      onUpdate in interface OperationListener<E>

    • getUIDProcessor

      public UIDProcessor getUIDProcessor()
      Description copied from interface: UIDProcessable

      Returns the UIDProcessor instance for this UIDProcessable object.


      Example Implementation

      private UIDProcessor uIDContainer;

 //...

 @Override
 public UIDProcessor getUIDProcessor()
 {
     if (uIDContainer == null) // Lazy Initialization
         uIDContainer = new UIDProcessor("group-name");
     return uIDContainer;
 }

      Details

      1. In most cases, it is recommended that UIDProcessor objects are stored as lazy-initialized singleton field variables as shown in the example above.
      Specified by:
      getUIDProcessor in interface UIDProcessable
      Returns:
      The UIDProcessor instance for this UIDProcessable object.
